Package frc.team1711.swerve.util.odometry

Class RobotTurn

  • java.lang.Object
    • frc.team1711.swerve.util.odometry.RobotTurn
  • public class RobotTurn
extends java.lang.Object
    Represents an autonomous robot turn, including both the turn itself and the way the robot makes the turn.
    See Also:
    RobotMovement, AutonDrive

    • Field Detail

      • NONE

        public static final RobotTurn NONE
        A RobotTurn describing no movement whatsoever.

    • Constructor Detail

      • RobotTurn

        public RobotTurn​(double direction,
                 FrameOfReference frameOfReference,
                 TurnManner manner)
        Creates a new RobotTurn instance.
        Parameters:
        direction - The double which represents the turn or final direction of the robot. An angle of zero is facing forwards or upwards on the xy plane, and as the angle increases it progresses clockwise. Measured in degrees.
        frameOfReference - The FrameOfReference for the final direction. If this is FrameOfReference.ROBOT, the given direction will be considered a turn relative to the robot's current position (i.e. a direction of 30 would represent a turn 30 degrees to the right from where the robot started the path). If frameOfReference is FrameOfReference.FIELD, then the direction will be relative to the field, based on however the robot's Position on the field was last reset with AutoSwerveDrive.resetPosition(Position).
        manner - A TurnManner which contains information on the way the turn is to be performed by the robot.

    • Method Detail

      • getManner

        public TurnManner getManner()
        Gets the TurnManner which describes how the robot should turn.
        Returns:
        The TurnManner associated with this autonomous turn.

      • toFieldRel

        public double toFieldRel​(Position position)
        Converts the direction to be field relative (if it isn't already explicitly field relative) given the robot's current Position.
        Parameters:
        position - The robot's Position on the field
        Returns:
        The equivalent field relative direction measured in degrees
